dir-section.heading: Provincial and Territorial Courts
dir-section.p: Provincial courts are constituted under provincial legislation; while their names may vary from province to province, their structures are generally similar. There are three levels of provincial courts.

The highest appellate court in a province (other than Newfoundland and Labrador) is the Court of Appeal. The highest court of first instance in each province, which hears serious criminal and civil cases, is variously known as the Court of King’s Bench, Supreme Court, Superior Court or Superior Court of Justice. Judges are appointed by the federal Government and are compulsorily retired at the age of 75 years.

All provinces, with the exception of Québec, have an intermediate level of courts, called County or District Courts. These possess immediate jurisdiction, dealing with criminal cases (apart from the most serious) and cases beyond the jurisdiction of the Small Claims Court. Judges are appointed by the federal Government; the compulsory age of retirement is 70 years.

Finally, each province has inferior courts which, with some variations, consist of the Juvenile Court, the Family Court, the Provincial Court (Criminal Division) and the Small Claims Court. These cover minor civil and criminal matters and settle the majority of such cases. Judges are appointed by the provincial governments and are compulsorily retired in accordance with the statues that established the respective courts—usually at the age of 70 years.

The superior courts of Nunavut and the Northwest Territories are presided over by the Chief Justice of Alberta, while the superior court of Yukon is presided over by the Chief Justice of British Columbia. The Nunavut Court of Justice is a single level court, which hears any type of case, including civil, family and criminal disputes, in both adult and youth courts.

dir-entry.dir-entry-name: Chief Justice of Newfoundland and Labrador
Chief Justice of Prince Edward Island

dir-section.heading: Alberta
dir-section.p: Alberta's Provincial Court (the lowest level of courts) includes the Family Division, the Youth Division, the Civil Division, the Traffic Division and the Criminal Division. There are 11 judicial districts, with headquarters at Calgary, Drumheller/Hanna, Edmonton, Fort McMurray, Grande Prairie, Lethbridge/Macleod, Medicine Hat, Peace River, Red Deer, St Paul and Wetaskiwin. The highest level of courts comprises the Court of Appeal and the Court of King's Bench.

dir-section.heading: Provincial Court
dir-section.p: The provincial court system comprises 72 locations and 136 full-time equivalent judges.

dir-section.heading: British Columbia
dir-section.p: British Columbia's highest provincial court is the Court of Appeal, followed by the Supreme Court. There are 15 Court of Appeal judges and 108 judges in the Supreme Court, who sit in 11 judicial districts. The Governor-General in Council appoints all provincial judges.

dir-section.heading: Provincial Court
dir-section.p: The provincial court system comprises more than 80 locations and around 150 judges.

dir-entry.dir-entry-name: Chief Judge of the Provincial Court

address.verbatim-address: 800 Hornby St, Suite 337, Vancouver, BC V6Z 2C5

dir-section.heading: Manitoba
dir-section.p: Manitoba has 15 administrative and judicial centres, situated in Beausejour, Brandon, Dauphin, Flin Flon, Killarney, Minnedosa, Morden, Portage la Prairie, Russell, Selkirk, Steinbach, Swan River, The Pas, Thompson and Virden. These handle Court of King's Bench and provincial court matters. The superior courts are the Court of Appeal and the Court of King’s Bench.

address.verbatim-address: Law Courts Bldg, Suite 100 e , 408 York Ave, Winnipeg, MB R3C 0P9
Law Courts Bldg, 408 York Ave, Winnipeg, MB R3C 0P9
Courthouse, Suite 100, 1104 Princess Ave, Brandon, MB R7A 0P9
114 River Ave W, Dauphin, MB R7N 0J7

dir-section.heading: Provincial Court
dir-section.p: There are six provincial court districts and 57 judges.

dir-section.heading: New Brunswick
dir-section.p: New Brunswick comprises eight judicial districts, with headquarters at Bathurst, Campbellton, Edmundston, Fredericton, Miramichi, Moncton, Saint John and Woodstock. The highest courts are the Court of Appeal and the Court of King's Bench, which is divided into a Trial Division and a Family Division.

address.verbatim-address: Justice Bldg, Rm 202, 427 Queen St, POB 6000, Fredericton, NB E3B 5H1
Justice Bldg, 427 Queen St, POB 6000, Fredericton, NB E3B 5H1

dir-section.heading: Provincial Court
dir-section.p: The Provincial Court of New Brunswick consists of a Chief Judge, an Associate Chief Judge, 20 judges, 9 supernumerary judges and 4 per diem judges. There are 11 permanent court locations.

dir-section.heading: Newfoundland and Labrador
dir-section.p: The Provincial Court of Newfoundland and Labrador is composed of Adult, Criminal, Youth, Small Claims, Family and Traffic Divisions. There are judicial centres situated at Clarenville, Corner Brook, Gander, Grand Bank, Grand Falls-Windsor, Happy Valley-Goose Bay, Harbour Grace, St John's, Stephenville and Wabush. The Court of Appeal is the highest court and the Supreme Court is divided into a General Division and a Family Division.

dir-section.heading: Supreme Court
dir-section.heading-note: Court House, 309 Duckworth St, POB 937, St John's, NL A1C 5M3; tel. (709) 729-1137; e-mail inquiries@supreme.court.nl.ca; internet court.nl.ca/supreme

dir-entry.dir-entry-name: Chief Justice of Newfoundland and Labrador

dir-section.heading: Provincial Court
dir-section.p: The provincial court system comprises a total of 10 permanent courts and 22 judges.

dir-section.heading: Northwest Territories
dir-section.p: The Northwest Territories has a Territorial Court, which includes a Wellness Court, Domestic Violence Treatment Options Court and a Civil Claims Division. Both judges and justices of the peace are appointed by the Territories' Commissioner. Court sessions are held in Yellowknife and on court circuits throughout the Territories. The superior courts of the Territories are the Court of Appeal and the Supreme Court. The Court of Appeal comprises the Chief Justice and judges from the Court of Appeal of Alberta and Saskatchewan and the judges and ex officio judges of the Supreme Court of the Northwest Territories and Yukon and the Nunavut Court of Justice.

address.verbatim-address: Courthouse, Suite 4903, 49th St, POB 550, Yellowknife, NT X1A 2N4
Courthouse, Suite 4903, 49th St, POB 550, Yellowknife, NT X1A 2N4

dir-section.heading: Territorial Court
dir-section.p: The Territorial Court comprises a Chief Judge and three other judges.

dir-section.heading: Nova Scotia
dir-section.p: Nova Scotia has seven county court districts. The Court of Appeal is the highest court in the province of Nova Scotia. The provincial Supreme Court has a separate Family Division. Supreme Court judges are appointed by the federal Government whereas Provincial Court judges are appointed by the provincial cabinet.

address.verbatim-address: The Law Courts, 1815 Upper Water St, Halifax, NS B3J 1S7
The Law Courts, 1815 Upper Water St, Halifax, NS B3J 1S7
3380 Devonshire Ave, Halifax, NS B3K 5R5

dir-section.heading: Provincial Court
dir-section.p: There are 11 main locations and 28 full-time and 12 part-time judges in the provincial court system.

dir-entry.dir-entry-name: Chief Judge of Provincial and Family Courts

dir-section.heading: Nunavut
dir-section.p: Following the division of the Northwest Territories in 1999, the Nunavut Court of Justice assumed the powers and functions formerly exercised by the Northwest Territories judicial system, with the exception of the territorial Court of Appeal. The Court of Appeal comprises the superior court judges of Nunavut, Yukon, Alberta and the Northwest Territories. The Nunavut Court of Justice is a single level court, which hears any type of case, including civil, family and criminal disputes, in both adult and youth courts. The Nunavut Court of Justice provides court services to approximately 95% of the communities across the Territory, through a travelling circuit court. There are some 80 justices of the peace in the territorial communities.

dir-section.heading: Court of Justice
dir-section.heading-note: Nunavut Justice Centre, Bldg 510, POB 297, Iqaluit, NU X0A 0H0; tel. (867) 975-6102; fax (867) 975-6550; email courtlibrary@gov.nu.ca; internet nunavutcourts.ca

dir-entry.dir-entry-name: Chief Justice of the Court of Justice

dir-section.heading: Ontario
dir-section.p: The Court of Ontario comprises two trial courts: the Superior Court of Justice (formerly the Ontario Court—General Division), which includes the Small Claims Court, the Divisional Court and the Family Court; and the Ontario Court of Justice (formerly the Ontario Court—Provincial Division). The province is divided into eight judicial districts.

dir-entry.dir-entry-name:
Associate Chief Justi
ce of Ontario

dir-section.heading: Prince Edward Island
dir-section.p: Prince Edward Island comprises three judicial counties, with headquarters at Georgetown, Charlottetown and Summerside. The Court of Appeal is the highest court in the province. The Supreme Court is the superior trial court and hears civil (including family) and criminal matters, appeals from administrative tribunals and appeals from the Provincial Court.

dir-section.heading: Court of Appeal
dir-section.heading-note: Sir Louis Henry Davies Law Courts Bldg, 42 Water St, POB 2000, Charlottetown, PE C1A 7N8; tel. (902) 368-6000; fax (902) 368-6123; internet www.courts.pe.ca/court-of-appeal

dir-entry.dir-entry-name: Chief Justice of Prince Edward Island

dir-section.heading: Provincial Court
dir-section.p: The Provincial Court comprises three courts, and three judges.

dir-section.heading: Québec
dir-section.p: Québec's court system differs from the court hierarchy of other provinces, in that it has no District Courts but a greater number of inferior courts. The main components include: the Court of Québec, which has Civil (includes the Small Claims Division), Criminal and Youth divisions; the Municipal Court; and the Court of Justices of the Peace, which issues warrants and enforces municipal by-laws. The highest courts in the province are the Court of Appeal and the Superior Court. The province is divided into 39 judicial districts.

Palais de justice de Québec, 300 blvd Jean-Lesage, Suite 427, Québec, QC G1K 8K6

dir-section.heading: Cour Supérieure (Superior Court)
dir-section.p: The Superior Court system comprises 13 courts and 145 fulltime judges.

300 blvd Jean-Lesage, Québec, QC G1K 8K6

dir-section.heading: Cour du Québec (Court of Québec)
dir-section.p: The Court of Québec operates in two regional sections and comprises 319 judges, including the Chief Justice and Associate Chief Justices, and 39 justices of the peace.

dir-section.heading: Saskatchewan
dir-section.p: The province of Saskatchewan has 15 judicial centres. The superior courts in the province are the Court of Appeal and the Court of King's Bench.

dir-section.heading: Provincial Court
dir-section.p: Saskatchewan’s provincial court system comprises 13 provincial court offices and 49 judges.

address.verbatim-address: 1815 Smith St, Regina, SK S4P 2N5

dir-section.heading: Yukon
dir-section.p: The superior courts of the Yukon territory are the Court of Appeal and the Supreme Court. The Court of Appeal is composed of justices from the Yukon Supreme Court, the Northwest Territories, Nunavut and the British Columbia Court of Appeal. The Supreme Court consists of three resident justices, 10 justices from the Northwest Territories and Nunavut, and 45 deputy judges from across Canada. Justices for both Courts are appointed by the federal Government.

address.verbatim-address: Court Registry, Law Courts, 2134 2nd Ave, Ground Floor, Whitehorse, YT Y1A 5H6

dir-entry.dir-entry-name: Chief Justice of the Supreme Court

dir-section.heading: Territorial Court
dir-section.p: The Territorial Court of Yukon consists of three fulltime judges and around 27 deputy judges. The Court sits permanently in Whitehorse and provides services to 14 other communities.
